wikipedia_page.main: Terry Cryer (24 June 1934 – 15 January 2017) was a British jazz and blues photographer. Described by Mojo as "The Dean of UK jazz and blues photographers", Cryer is best known for portraits of some of the genre's most renowned performers.

response: She has written about photography and interviewed practitioners including Eve Arnold,Wilmer, Val, '"The Unretouched Woman" [Eve Arnold], Spare Rib, No. 61, August 1977. p. 41. Anthony Barboza,Wilmer, Val, "Barboza: The Music of Ourselves", Ten.8, No. 24, 1986. Roy DeCarava,Wilmer, Val, "Roy DeCarava: An Uncommon Beauty", Ten.8, No. 27; "No Crystal Stair", New Statesman, 22 January 1988; "Real People", City Limits, 21–28 January 1988; letter responding to obituary, The Guardian, 21 November 2009. Terry Cryer,Wilmer, Val, "Through a Lens, Darkly", The Wire, Issue 62, April 1989; "Introduction", Terry Cryer, One in the Eye, 1993. Milt Hinton,Wilmer, Val, "Milt Hinton: a Musical Vision", Ten.8, Vol. 2, No. 1, Spring 1991; obituary, The Guardian, 16 January 2001. John Hopkins,Wilmer, Val, "Shooting Jazz", in John "Hoppy" Hopkins, From the Hip, London, 2008. Danny Lyon,Wilmer, Val, "Early Days of Rage", The Independent on Sunday Review, 22 November 1992, pp. 8–9, 12–13, 15. Raissa Page (of Greenham Common fame), Coreen Simpson,Wilmer, Val, "Corinne Simpson: Taking Care of Business", Ten.8, No. 24, 1986. Beuford SmithWilmer, Val, "Beuford Smith: In the Humane Tradition", Ten.8, No. 16, 1985. and James Van Der Zee.Wilmer, Val, "Harlem's Picture-Taking Man", The Observer Magazine, 21 September 1980, pp. 48–49, 51, 53; "Van Der Zee: Harlem Photographer", Ten.8, No. 16, 1985. In the 1980s, Wilmer compiled and edited the "Evidence" issue of Ten.8 magazine devoted to the work of African-American photographers.TEN-8 No. 24: "Evidence – New Light on Afro American Images", n.d. (1987?). Wilmer's work has often been used in conjunction with music albums, as in the digipak booklet for Honest Jon's London is the Place for Me no. 4 CD, which includes photographs by her that "are full of warmth and immediacy".Walters, John L., "Reason and rhymes: Can design for contemporary jazz, world and experimental music have a meaningful partnership with the musical content?", Eye magazine, 63, Spring 2007.
